text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 4.23.7, Employment Tax, Employment Tax on Tip Income.

IRM 4.23.7.4.1 (10). Changed three attachments to two, removing Publication 5080 FAQs as they were already mailed with the Letter 4520-P, the Section 3121(q) Pre-notice for Employer Share of Tax Based on Form 4137.

IRM 4.23.7.4.1 (11). Removed business from the statement, “The date of the Section 3121(q) Notice and Demand will be the last day of the quarter in which the Letter 4520 is issued, not the mailing date of the letter”. Should be the last day of the quarter.

IRM 4.23.7.7 (6-11). New sections adding information on the scope of a tip audit, incorporating Interim Guidance Memorandum SBSE-04-0720-0059, issued July 26, 2020, Interim Guidance on the Requirement to Consider Expanding the Scope of an Examination Selected and Assigned as a Tip Audit Case. Includes additional instructions.
IRM 4.23.7.7.1. Subsection title changed to Scope of Tip Examination and deleted (1).

IRM 4.23.7.7.4 (6). Removed business from the statement, “Therefore, the date on the Section 3121(q) Notice and Demand should be postdated with the last business day of the quarter.” Updated example to read the date as March 31, 2012 (not 30).

Exhibit 4.23.7.10 (1). Modiﬁed statement to read, “The Tip Rate Determination and Education Program (TRD/EP) was designed to promote compliance by industry employers and employees the provisions of the Internal Revenue Code relating to tip income and to reduce disputes under Section 3121(q). The TRD/EP was established in the early 1990’s. Tip Agreements were designed enhance administration of the tip program by both the Employer and the IRS and to facilitate and promote the use of current ﬁnancial information technology in the tip reporting process.” This statement provides the history and introduces the voluntary compliance feature available in the tip industry.
IRM 4.23.7.10.4. Examples included on revocation of tip agreement.
New subsections 4.23.7.10.6.3 to 4.23.7.10.6.21 are replacing 4.23.7.10.6.3, 4.23.7.10.6.4, and 4.23.7.10.6.5, as well as 4.23.7.11. Please see the current list below.

) Purpose: This section details the basic structure of Tip Examinations and Tip Rate Review process. (

) Audience: This section contains instructions and guidelines for all Large Business and International (LB&I), Tax Exempt/Government Entities (TE/GE), and Small Business/Self-Employed (SB/SE) employees dealing with Tip nations and Tip Rate Review procedures. (
) Policy Owner: Director, Examination - Specialty Policy of the Small Self-Employed Division. (
) Program Owner: Program Manager – National Tip Reporting Compliance Program (NTRCP). (

) The mission of Employment Tax National Tip Reporting Compliance Program (NTRCP) Territory is to develop and implement policies and strategies for tip income ﬁling, payment (withholding), and reporting compliance. (

) Tipping has been a historical area of underreporting and is subject to unique laws and regulations. Traditional examinations often are burdensome to both the taxpayer and the Service. NTRCP has developed voluntary tools, most predominantly tip agreements, which address employer and employee ance. (

) This section provides guidance on general tip examinations and voluntary pliance tools for taxpayers in the tipping industry. Examiners should also to tip training materials for additional guidance. (

) NTRCP is governed by Policy Statements and other internal guidance that apply to all IRS personnel regardless of operating division. The Policy State- ments found in IRM

, Servicewide Policies and Authorities, Policies of Internal Revenue Service, apply to all employment tax issues and examina- tions. Reviewers should review these Policy Statements to properly perform their examination duties. (

, the employer is responsible for deducting and depositing the employee’s share of social security and Medicare tax on tips. tips should be included in a written report furnished by the employee to the employer. The employer must withhold to the extent that collection can be made from the employee’s funds on or after the time the written statement is furnished. The employee’s funds include wages (exclusive of tips) in the em- ployer’s possession and amounts turned over to the employer by the employee. (

) If the employee does not provide enough money, the employer will apply the employee’s regular pay and any money the employee gives to the employer the taxes in the following order: a. Social security and Medicare or railroad retirement taxes on the ee’s regular wages, b. Federal, state, and local income taxes on the employee’s regular c. Social security and Medicare taxes or railroad retirement taxes on the employee’s reported tips, and d. Federal, state, and local income taxes on the employee’s reported tips. Any taxes that remain unpaid can be collected by the employer from the ployee’s next paycheck. If withholding taxes remain uncollected at the end the year, the employee may be subject to a penalty for underpayment of estimated taxes. (

) An employer may prescribe regularly used electronic forms for use by employees for reporting tips. If an electronic statement is used, the system must ensure that the information received is the information by the employee. The system must document all occasions of access that result in the transmission of a tip statement. In addition, the design and operation of the electronic system, including access procedures, must make reasonably certain that the person accessing the system and transmitting statement is the employee identiﬁed in the statement transmitted. Any elec- tronic statement must include the same information set out above in (

The elec- tronic signature must identify the employee transmitting the electronic tip statement and must authenticate and verify the transmission. Form 4137 shows the individual EIN(s) and the employee’s unreported tips for each of the employers for whom the employee worked for during the year. Form 4137 allows the IRS to aggregate unreported tips reported on Forms 4137 for each employer. This allows the IRS to provide each employer with a Section 3121(q) Notice and Demand for the employer’s share of the applicable FICA due on the tips their employees reported to the IRS but did not report to the employer.

) In the area of tip income reporting, employers and business owners at times mis-characterize certain payments. Examiners need to be alert for situations where payments for services are inappropriately structured or incorrectly clas- siﬁed. Mis-classiﬁcation of payments may result in incorrect information return reporting and/or underpayment of employment taxes. (
) Certain payments to drivers of taxicabs, limousines, tour buses, and other modes of transportation may have been mis-characterized by employees, employers, or business owners as tips. (

) This may occur in situations that involve drivers who are employees of companies engaged in the business of transporting passengers for a fare limousines and taxicabs). The drivers pick up and transport passengers to requested destinations. Typically, the driver collects the fares from the passenger. It is customary for the passenger to tip the driver an amount in addition to the fare for the transportation provided. At issue are other the driver may receive in addition to the tips from the passenger. (

) Some business establishments such as adult entertainment clubs, nightclubs, and other service establishments have a practice of making payments to drivers who bring passengers to their establishments. a. Generally, the service establishment’s personnel will not render payment to the driver until the passenger ﬁrst pays a cover charge or otherwise indicates in some manner that they are patrons of the service establish- ment. b. Payments by establishments to drivers are usually made in cash, although some establishments issue vouchers to the drivers that can be exchanged for cash at a later time. c. The amount of the cash or voucher payment may or may not bear any relationship to the transportation fare, may vary depending upon the number of patrons, and may be far greater than either the fare or the customary tip for the transportation. d. In many situations, one or more passengers are transported from a location such as a hotel directly to the establishment. In some cases, driver may make agreements with certain hotel personnel so that when guest wants to go to an establishment (e.g., hotel guest informs hotel personnel that they are interested in ﬁnding an adult entertainment the hotel personnel will summon the driver with whom they have an agreement from the hotel’s transportation queue and the driver will split the payment from the establishment with the hotel personnel.
Note: Additional Medicare Tax is only imposed on the employee. There is no employer share of Additional Medicare Tax.

) On June

, the Supreme Court rendered a decision in favor of the in U.S. v. Fior d’Italia, Inc., The Court determined that the IRS has the to assess the employer’s share of social security and Medicare taxes due on employees’ tip income using an aggregate estimation method. In light of this case, the IRS may generally conduct tip examinations and make for social security and Medicare taxes on employers only, without ﬁrst examining the tip records of the individual employees. ) When tip income is an issue, the examiner should determine whether employees are reporting tips to their employer and if the employer is ing employment taxes as required. The examiner should determine if the amount of tip income reported is reasonably correct. At a minimum, the examiner should consider the following: a. Nature of the establishment. Employees of ﬁne dining restaurants generally receive more tips than those of less expensive restaurants since tips are generally a percentage of the customer’s bill. The same would apply to tips paid to employees of expensive hotels, beauty etc. b. Method of payment. Does the establishment accept cash, checks, cards, debit cards, or charge accounts? Are all types of payment as tip income by the employee? c. Geographical location of the establishment. Different areas have varying tipping habits. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

uatters v. Commissioner, T.C. Memo,
In M

uatters, the stiff rate (term used when a customer does not tip the server) was applied to the gross sales. With the increased use of credit cards and debit cards, the volume of charge sales that include a tip have also increased. Therefore, applying a stiff factor to sales would not be appropriate. In tip examinations, the examiner should apply the stiff rate only to cash sales and charge sales that did not have a tip added to the bill. The stiff factor should not be applied to charge sales including a tip amount. To obtain an electronic version of the calculation worksheet to use, contact an analyst with NTRCP. B credit applies to employers who operate a food or beverage es- tablishment where tipping is customary and where food or beverages are served for either on- or off-premises consumption. IRC

B allows an income tax credit to food and beverage businesses for the share of employer’s FICA taxes paid with respect to certain employees’ tip wages. The employer can claim the income tax credit whether or not the employee reports the tip wages to the employer. Form

, Credit for Employer Social Security and Taxes Paid on Certain Employee Tips, is used to compute the credit. Note: Additional Medicare Tax is only imposed on the employee. There is no employer share of Additional Medicare Tax. Thus, Additional Medicare Tax has no effect on an employer’s IRC
B credit. (

) These voluntary tip compliance agreements help reduce taxpayer burden narily associated with the IRS assessments of additional FICA taxes on unreported tip income. The IRS, through outreach and education, helps business owners and their tipped employees understand the tax laws related to tip income reporting so that they can more accurately meet their reporting and ﬁling obligations. (
) The employer can choose not to enter into the program, but instead, its own program or actions to bring itself and its employees into compliance. (

) The TRD/EP is a voluntary program for both the employer and the IRS. Employers are screened for suitability. Screenings do not increase the likeli- hood of an audit. Employers can request a tip agreement or choose not to participate in the program at all. An employer who participates can only have one agreement at a time. The various agreements can be accessed at under Market Segment Understandings. (

) There are speciﬁc tip compliance agreements for the food and beverage, metology and barber, and gaming (casino) industries. There are also generic tip agreements that permit all other tipping industries to participate in the program. The TRDA and TRAC agreements are available to employers in all industries, including restaurants and bars, salons and barber shops, taxicab and limousine companies, airport skycap companies, car wash operations, tour guide companies. The GITCA is available only to employers in the industry. The E
RAC is available only to food and beverage employers. (

) Some employers will ﬁnd one agreement more beneﬁcial, some will prefer another agreement, and some will choose not to participate in the program all. ) The IRS will work with the employer throughout the agreement process to establish reasonable tip rates and to educate the employer concerning its rights and responsibilities as provided for in the agreement. (

) The employer has the primary responsibility for administering the terms and rates of the agreement once it is signed. However, the IRS is available to assist the employer with questions regarding the administration of the agreement and the employer’s related reporting requirements. (

) The IRS may not examine a participating employee’s tip income for any taxable year that ends after the effective date of the agreement, as long as participating employee fulﬁlls his or her responsibilities as provided in the agreement and Gaming Employee Tip Reporting Agreement. (

) The IRS may not examine the tip income of a participating employee for taxable year that ends on or before the effective date of the agreement provided that during that prior period the employee was: a. A participant under a predecessor agreement (such as a Tip Rate mination Agreement (TRDA)) and satisﬁed all the terms and that agreement, b. A participating employee under another employer who had a GITCA predecessor agreement and satisﬁed all the terms of that agreement, c. An employer where the individual was not an eligible employee. (
) The IRS may continue any ongoing examination of any employees of the employer begun by the IRS before the effective date of the agreement. (
) A nonparticipating employee is subject to the full range of compliance and forcement procedures of the IRS at any time. (
) During any taxable year that the agreement is in effect, the IRS may not assess additional tax against the employer pursuant to IRC

(q) with respect to the tip income of participating employees unless the participating employee reports additional tip income on his/her federal income tax return. The IRS may assert a liability against the employer pursuant to IRC based on tips received by a nonparticipating employee if the asserted is based upon the ﬁnal results of an audit or agreement of the employee or the reporting of additional tip income by an employee. ) The burden to examine tip income will be less for the IRS as a result of executed tip agreements and employee participation. (
) The IRS will receive a more consistent stream of revenue generated from ﬁlings of employers and employees.

) An initial agreement for a new Property or newly opened outlet within an tablished Property requires the Reviewer to prepare rates based on comparables. Comparables are rates calculated using similar properties have established tip rates. Items to consider are staffing (for e.g. overstaff ensure good customer service may mean lower tips), proximity between customer and employee (e.g., shorter walks to deliver food and drinks means higher sales and tips), cost to play or eat (e.g., high priced menu usually mean higher tip rates). To begin the process: a. Ask the Property who they see as its competitors. The Property identify the expected customer base and name three to ﬁve or competitive Properties. (Remember: high-end Properties compete high-end Properties, not value-minded Properties) b. Research newspaper articles on the building, planning or licensing of Property for comments from management and owners c. Consider similar Properties owned or related to the Newly Opened Property. d. It is important to remember that similar Properties do not have to be located in the same region but should share some general features; e. Develop rates using an average for each occupation at the Properties to determine the proposed comparable rates for the new Property. f. Review the proposed rates for reasonableness and adjust, as based upon any known factors that may affect the rates g. Do not disclose the Properties used to prepare the comparable rates h. ) Reviewers will provide formula templates and instructions on how to the templates to the Property. See NTRCP Letters, Forms and Publications, and lists of formulas available on the repository. (

) Parameters, or subjective factors, determines the Cash Differential and Stiff Rate used in the templates. The Cash Differential is the difference between cash and charge tip rates. In general, the Cash Differential is usually
percent-

percent less than the charge tip rate depending on the type of taurant, composition of tender and clientele. The Stiff Factor is referred to percentage of customers who leave no tip. Note: The stiff factor is applied only to “cash receipts.” Cash receipts include receipts paid in cash, or charge receipts that did not leave a tip (comp are also treated as receipts paid in cash and may be subject to a cash ential and stiff factor). Charged receipts with a charged tip have a deﬁnite so the stiff would not be applied to these receipts. (

) In the Streamline Method, the Property completes the template and requested documentation to the Reviewer to test the accuracy of the tion. Reviewers will request the basis for subjective factors if they don’t the parameter guidelines. For example, ask the Property how the stiff rate determined. If the basis does not appear reasonable, the Reviewer may to develop additional observations to verify the accuracy of the subjective factors. (

) In the Traditional Method, the Reviewer completes the templates based on information to complete the template (POS Reports, payroll information and notes from interviews). ) Reviewer will complete the official list of the rates and the agreement. The Reviewer will input the calculated rates into the Non-Participant Rates The Non- Participant rate is the audit standard. Next the Reviewer will apply coverage adjustment to arrive at the Participant rate as recorded on the document listing the rates. (

) ) A coverage adjustment is an audit technique the IRS uses. It is a cal methodology to determine the tip rates for non-participants and participants. First, a calculation of the average tip rate is completed based the Property’s historical data. Once an average tip rate is determined, a coverage adjustment may be applied to the participant. A coverage is similar to the mathematical concept of a standard deviation. The purpose to achieve a rate that encourages a majority participation and is based on dispersion of customary tipping practices in different outlets for different services or transactions. (
